newsitem.title: UK: British pension giant bets on stocks crash - paper.
newsitem.headline: British pension giant bets on stocks crash - paper.

text.p: A leading British pension management group is so sure stock markets are about to crash that it has built up a huge cash mountain despite criticism from clients, the Guardian newspaper said on Wednesday.

It said PDFM Ltd, which controls funds worth 50 billion pounds ($78 billion), had amassed a cash pile of seven billion pounds ($11 billion) since January 1995, when it decided to keep 15 percent of its assets in cash.
In that period London's FT all-share index has risen by a third, effectively costing PDFM Ltd three billion pounds ($4.5 billion), the Guardian said.
PDFM Ltd marketing director Paul Yates said despite criticism from some major clients for underperforming the market, the firm would stick to its guns and continue to reduce share holdings.
"The degree of over-valuation in the UK and U.S. stock markets is unprecedented," he said.

"We have had a lot of work explaining our strategy to clients. We have had a very difficult year. But in the longer term people know we have got things right and if we changed tack now, half our clients would probably walk out."
PDFM Ltd is part of the investment banking conglomerate Union Bank of Switzerland.
